task.Question: How many studio albums were published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009 (included)? You can use the latest 2022 version of english wikipedia.

Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. I did a search for Mercedes Sosa
2. I went to the Wikipedia page for her
3. I scrolled down to "Studio albums"
4. I counted the ones between 2000 and 2009

steps.content: How many studio albums were published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009 (included)? You can use the latest 2022 version of english wikipedia.

steps.reasoning:
1. Perform a WebSearch for "Mercedes Sosa discography" to find relevant information about her studio albums.
   
2. If the search results include a link to her Wikipedia page, use the Browser tool to open that page. If not, perform another search specifically for "Mercedes Sosa Wikipedia" to locate her page.

3. Once on the Wikipedia page, look for the section that lists her studio albums.

4. Identify the studio albums released between 2000 and 2009, inclusive. Make a note of the titles and release years.

5. Count the number of albums identified in step 4.

6. If there are any discrepancies or unclear information, consider performing a secondary WebSearch for "Mercedes Sosa albums released 2000-2009" to verify the findings. 

7. Compile the final count of studio albums published by Mercedes Sosa during the specified period.

1. The specific facts given in the request are: 
   - The artist is Mercedes Sosa.
   - The time frame for the studio albums is between 2000 and 2009 (inclusive).

2. Facts that may need to be looked up include:
   - The number of studio albums published by Mercedes Sosa during the specified period. This information can be found on her Wikipedia page or in her discography.

3. No facts need to be derived through logical deduction, simulation, or computation for this request.

4. There are no recalled facts, hunches, or well-reasoned guesses relevant to this request.

serp.title: Mercedes Sosa
serp.content: Compilation albums ; 1983, Recital. Label: Philips ; 1988, Amigos Míos. Label: Philips ; 1993, 30 Años. Label: Polygram Argentina ; 1995, Oro. Label: Polygram.

serp.title: Cantora, un Viaje Íntimo
serp.content: Cantora, An Intimate Journey is a double album by Argentine singer Mercedes Sosa, released on 2009 through Sony Music Argentina.

    From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    note
      Not to be confused with
      BID:663 link Mercedes Sola
      .
    table

          gridcell
    
      Haydée Mercedes
      "
      La Negra
      "
      Sosa
      (
      Latin American Spanish:
      
      BID:728 link [meɾˈseðes ˈsosa]
      ; 9 July 1935
      superscript
        BID:731 link [1]
      – 4 October 2009) was an
      BID:734 link Argentine
      singer who was popular throughout
      BID:735 link Latin America
      and many countries outside the region. With her roots in
      BID:736 link Argentine folk music
      , Sosa became one of the preeminent exponents of
      El nuevo cancionero
      . She gave voice to songs written by many Latin American songwriters. Her music made people hail her as the "voice of the voiceless ones".
      superscript
        BID:739 link [2]
      She was often called "the conscience of Latin America".
      superscript
        BID:743 link [3]
    
      Sosa performed in venues such as the
      BID:747 link Lincoln Center
      in New York City, the
      BID:748 link Théâtre Mogador
      in Paris, the
      BID:749 link Sistine Chapel
      in Vatican City, as well as sold-out shows in New York's
      BID:750 link Carnegie Hall
      and the Roman
      BID:751 link Colosseum
      during her final decade of life. Her career spanned four decades and she was the recipient of six
      BID:752 link Latin Grammy
      awards (2000, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2009, 2011), including a
      BID:753 link Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award
      in 2004 and two posthumous
      BID:754 link Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album
      in 2009 and 2011. She won the
      BID:755 link Premio Gardel
      in 2000, the main musical award in Argentina. She served as an ambassador for
      BID:756 link UNICEF
      .
    heading Life
      Life
    ​
    [
    BID:762 link edit
    ]
    
      Sosa was born on 9 July 1935, in
      BID:766 link San Miguel de Tucumán
      , in the
      BID:767 link northwestern Argentine
      province of
      BID:768 link Tucumán
      , of
      BID:769 link mestizo
      ancestry. She was of French, Spanish and
      BID:770 link Diaguita
      descent.
      superscript
        BID:772 link [4]
      Her parents, a day laborer and a washerwoman,
      superscript
        BID:776 link [5]
      were
      BID:779 link Peronists
      , although they never registered in the party, and she started her career as a singer for the
      BID:780 link Peronist Party
      in
      BID:781 link Tucuman
      under the name Gladys Osorio.
      superscript
        BID:783 link [6]
      In 1950, at age fifteen, she won a singing competition organized by a local radio station and was given a contract to perform for two months.
      superscript
        BID:787 link [7]
      She recorded her first album,
      BID:791 link La Voz de la Zafra
      , in 1959.
      superscript
        BID:793 link [7]
      A performance at the 1965
      BID:796 link Cosquín National Folklore Festival
      —where she was introduced and brought to the stage while sitting in the audience by fellow folk singer
      BID:797 link Jorge Cafrune
      —
      superscript
        BID:799 link [8]
      brought her to the attention of the Argentine public.
      superscript
        BID:803 link [7]
      Sosa and her first husband,
      BID:806 link Manuel Oscar Matus
      , with whom she had one son, were key players in the mid-60s
      BID:808 link nueva canción
      movement (which was called
      nuevo cancionero
      in Argentina).
      superscript
        BID:811 link [9]
      Her second record was
      Canciones con Fundamento
      , a collection of Argentine folk songs.
    figure, details=''
      BID:816 link
      Figcaption
        Sosa with
        BID:819 link Félix Luna
        and
        BID:820 link Ariel Ramírez
        (at the piano)
    
      Sosa "spent the late 1960s building her audience in Europe and among the cosmopolitan middle class in Buenos Aires, becoming in the process a much bigger star" than her contemporaries.
      superscript
        BID:823 link [10]
      In 1967, Sosa toured the United States and Europe with great success.
      superscript
        [
        BID:828 link citation needed
        ]
      In later years, she performed and recorded extensively, broadening her repertoire to include material from throughout Latin America.
    
      In the early 1970s, Sosa released two concept albums in collaboration with composer
      BID:831 link Ariel Ramírez
      and lyricist
      BID:832 link Félix Luna
      :
      Cantata Sudamericana
      and
      Mujeres Argentinas
      (Argentine Women). She also recorded a tribute to Chilean musician
      BID:835 link Violeta Parra
      in 1971, including what was to become one of Sosa's signature songs,
      BID:837 link Gracias a la vida
      .
      superscript
        BID:839 link [4]
      superscript
        BID:843 link [11]
      She further popularized of songs written by
      BID:846 link Milton Nascimento
      of Brazil and
      BID:847 link Pablo Milanés
      and
      BID:848 link Silvio Rodríguez
      both from
      BID:849 link Cuba
      .
      superscript
        BID:851 link [4]
    figure, details=''
      BID:855 link
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 1972
    
      After the
      BID:859 link military junta
      of
      BID:860 link Jorge Videla
      came to power in 1976, the atmosphere in Argentina grew increasingly oppressive. Sosa faced death threats against both her and her family, but refused for many years to leave the country. At a concert in
      BID:861 link La Plata
      in 1979, Sosa was searched and arrested on stage, along with all those attending the concert.
      superscript
        BID:863 link [9]
      Their release came about through international intervention.
      superscript
        BID:867 link [7]
      Banned in her own country, she moved to Paris and then to
      BID:870 link Madrid
      .
      superscript
        BID:872 link [7]
      superscript
        BID:876 link [9]
    
      Sosa returned to Argentina from her exile in Europe in 1982,
      superscript
        BID:881 link [9]
      several months before the military regime collapsed as a result of the
      BID:884 link Falklands War
      , and gave a series of concerts at the
      BID:886 link Teatro Ópera
      in Buenos Aires, where she invited many of her younger colleagues to share the stage. A double album of recordings from these performances became an instant best seller. In subsequent years, Sosa continued to tour both in Argentina and abroad, performing in such venues as the
      BID:887 link Lincoln Center
      in New York City and the
      BID:889 link Théâtre Mogador
      in Paris. In poor health for much of the 1990s, she performed a comeback show in Argentina in 1998.
      superscript
        BID:891 link [7]
      In 1994, she played in the
      BID:894 link Sistine Chapel
      in Vatican City.
      superscript
        BID:896 link [4]
      In 2002, she sold out both
      BID:899 link Carnegie Hall
      in New York and the
      BID:900 link Colosseum
      in Rome in the same year.
      superscript
        BID:902 link [4]
    figure, details=''
      BID:906 link
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 1973
    
      A supporter of
      BID:910 link Perón
      , she favored leftist causes throughout her life. She opposed President
      BID:911 link Carlos Menem
      , who was in office from 1989 to 1999, and supported the election of
      BID:912 link Néstor Kirchner
      , who became president in 2003.
      superscript
        BID:914 link [12]
      Sosa was a
      BID:917 link UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador
      for Latin America and the Caribbean.
      superscript
        BID:919 link [9]
      superscript
        BID:923 link [13]
    
      Sosa disliked being identified as a protest singer.
      superscript
        BID:928 link [14]
      
      superscript
        BID:932 link [15]
      While she was outright in her political stances, Sosa said the following on the position of the artist:
    blockquote
      
        “An artist isn’t political in the party political sense – they have a constituency, which is their public – it is the poetry that matters most of all.”
    
      In a career spanning four decades, she worked with performers across several genres and generations, folk, opera, pop, rock, including
      BID:939 link Martha Argerich
      ,
      BID:940 link Andrea Bocelli
      ,
      BID:941 link David Broza
      ,
      BID:942 link Franco Battiato
      ,
      BID:943 link Jaime Roos
      ,
      BID:944 link Joan Baez
      ,
      BID:945 link Francis Cabrel
      ,
      BID:946 link Gal Costa
      ,
      BID:947 link Luz Casal
      ,
      BID:948 link Lila Downs
      ,
      BID:949 link Lucio Dalla
      ,
      BID:950 link Maria Farantouri
      ,
      BID:951 link Lucecita Benitez
      ,
      BID:952 link Nilda Fernández
      ,
      BID:953 link Charly Garcia
      ,
      BID:954 link León Gieco
      ,
      BID:955 link Gian Marco
      ,
      BID:956 link Nana Mouskouri
      ,
      BID:957 link Pablo Milanés
      ,
      BID:958 link Holly Near
      ,
      BID:959 link Milton Nascimento
      ,
      BID:960 link Pata Negra
      ,
      BID:961 link Fito Páez
      ,
      BID:962 link Franco De Vita
      ,
      BID:963 link Lourdes Pérez
      ,
      BID:964 link Luciano Pavarotti
      ,
      BID:965 link Silvio Rodríguez
      ,
      BID:966 link Ismael Serrano
      ,
      BID:967 link Shakira
      ,
      BID:968 link Sting
      ,
      BID:969 link Caetano Veloso
      ,
      superscript
        BID:971 link [4]
      
      BID:974 link Julieta Venegas
      ,
      BID:975 link Gustavo Cerati
      and
      BID:976 link Konstantin Wecker
      superscript
        BID:978 link [9]
    
      Sosa participated in a 1999 production of
      BID:982 link Ariel Ramírez
      's
      Misa Criolla
      .
      superscript
        BID:985 link [16]
      Her song
      Balderrama
      is featured in the 2008 movie
      BID:990 link Che
      , starring
      BID:991 link Benicio del Toro
      as the Argentine
      BID:992 link Marxist
      revolutionary
      BID:993 link Che Guevara
      .
      superscript
        BID:995 link [17]
    
      Sosa was the co-chair of the
      BID:999 link Earth Charter
      International Commission.
    heading Awards
      Awards
    ​
    [
    BID:1004 link edit
    ]
    
      Sosa won the
      BID:1008 link Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album
      in 2000 (
      Misa Criolla
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1011 link [18]
      2003 (
      Acústico
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1016 link [19]
      2006 (
      Corazón Libre
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1021 link [20]
      2009 (
      BID:1025 link Cantora 1
      , which also won
      BID:1026 link Best Recording Package
      and was nominated for
      BID:1027 link Album of the Year
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1029 link [21]
      and 2011 (
      Deja La Vida Volar
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1034 link [22]
      as well as several international awards.
    
      In 1995,
      BID:1038 link Konex Foundation
      from Argentina granted her the Diamond
      BID:1039 link Konex Award
      , one of the most prestigious awards in Argentina, as the most important personality in the popular music of her country in the last decade.
      superscript
        BID:1041 link [23]
    heading Death
      Death
    ​
    [
    BID:1048 link edit
    ]
    figure, details=''
      BID:1052 link
      Figcaption
        Mercedes Sosa lying in repose, with her family and President
        BID:1055 link Cristina Fernández de Kirchner
        viewing
    
      Suffering from recurrent
      BID:1057 link endocrine
      and
      BID:1058 link respiratory
      problems in later years, the 74-year-old Sosa was hospitalized in Buenos Aires on 18 September 2009.
      superscript
        BID:1060 link [24]
      She died from
      BID:1063 link multiple organ failure
      on 4 October 2009, at 5:15 am.
      superscript
        BID:1065 link [11]
      She is survived by one son, Fabián Matus, born of her first marriage.
      superscript
        BID:1069 link [7]
      superscript
        BID:1073 link [25]
      He said: "She lived her 74 years to the fullest. She had done practically everything she wanted, she didn't have any type of barrier or any type of fear that limited her".
      superscript
        BID:1077 link [25]
      The hospital expressed its sympathies to her relatives.
      superscript
        BID:1081 link [26]
      Her website featured the following: "Her undisputed talent, her honesty and her profound convictions leave a great legacy to future generations".
      superscript
        BID:1085 link [27]
    
      Her body was placed on display at the
      BID:1089 link National Congress
      building in Buenos Aires for the public to pay their respects, and President Fernández de Kirchner ordered three days of national mourning.
      superscript
        BID:1091 link [25]
      superscript
        BID:1095 link [28]
      Thousands had queued by the end of the day.
      superscript
        BID:1099 link [27]
      superscript
        BID:1103 link [29]
    
      Sosa's obituary in
      BID:1108 link The Daily Telegraph
      said she was "an unrivalled interpreter of works by her compatriot, the Argentine
      BID:1109 link Atahualpa Yupanqui
      , and Chile's
      BID:1110 link Violeta Parra
      ".
      superscript
        BID:1112 link [7]
      Helen Popper of
      BID:1115 link Reuters
      reported her death by saying she "fought South America's dictators with her voice and became a giant of contemporary Latin American music".
      superscript
        BID:1117 link [29]
      Sosa received three
      BID:1120 link Latin Grammy
      nominations for her album, in 2009 . She went on to win Best Folk Album about a month after her death.
      superscript
        BID:1122 link [4]
      superscript
        BID:1126 link [9]
    heading Tributes
      Tributes
    ​
    [
    BID:1133 link edit
    ]
    
      In 2019, Sosa was celebrated by a
      BID:1137 link Google Doodle
      . The doodle was showcased in
      BID:1138 link Argentina
      ,
      BID:1139 link Chile
      ,
      BID:1140 link Uruguay
      ,
      BID:1141 link Paraguay
      ,
      BID:1142 link Bolivia
      ,
      BID:1143 link Peru
      ,
      BID:1144 link Ecuador
      ,
      BID:1145 link Cuba
      ,
      BID:1146 link Iceland
      , Sweden,
      BID:1147 link Serbia
      ,
      BID:1148 link Greece
      ,
      BID:1149 link Israel
      and
      BID:1150 link Vietnam
      .
      superscript
        BID:1152 link [30]
    
      In 2023,
      BID:1157 link Rolling Stone
      ranked Sosa at number 160 on its list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time.
      superscript
        BID:1159 link [31]
    heading Discography
      Discography
    ​
    [
    BID:1166 link edit
    ]
    figure, details=''
      BID:1170 link
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 2005, with Argentina's then-First Lady (later president from 2007 to 2015), Cristina Fernández de Kirchner
    
      Sosa recorded forty albums.
      superscript
        BID:1175 link [4]
      superscript
        BID:1179 link [9]

steps.overview: Identified that Mercedes Sosa released two studio albums between 2000 and 2009: 'Corazón Libre' (2005) and 'Cantora 1' (2009).
steps.long_answer: Mercedes Sosa published two studio albums between 2000 and 2009: 'Corazón Libre' in 2005 and 'Cantora 1' in 2009.
